title: Shell plating
text:
Shell plating is the outer-most structure on the <a href="Hull%20%28watercraft%29">hull</a> of a <a href="steel">steel</a> or <a href="aluminum">aluminum</a> <a href="ship">ship</a> or <a href="boat">boat</a>.
Strakes.
A <a href="strake">strake</a> is the name given to each line of planking in a wooden vessel. In modern ship construction it refers to the longitudinal run of plating covering the hull, deck and bulkhead structure. Certain specific strakes are uniquely identified:
<a href="Keel">Keel</a>: is a special strake of the Bottom plating extending from the centerplane outboard.
Bottom: the Bottom Shell plate strakes extend from the Keel to the Bilge.
<a href="Bilge">Bilge</a>: is the plating which transitions from the more-or-less horizontal Bottom Shell to the more-or-less vertical Side Shell and is generally curved. See also <a href="Chine%20%28boating%29">Chine (boating)</a>.
Side: is the plating which extends from the Bilge strake(s) to the Shear strake.
Shear: is a special strake of the Side plating. It is the strake that connects the Side Shell to the Strength Deck.
Stringer: is a special strake of the Strength Deck plating. It is the strake that connects the Strength Deck to the Side Shell.
Strength Deck: is a special deck. It is normally the uppermost continuous deck and forms the top flange of the hull girder.
